title: 91K3O
name: Donald Newman
description: Responsible for supervising and performing maintenance and repairs on the mechanisms and systems of tank turrets, tank weapons, fighting vehicles, small arms and other infantry weapons. Duties included: Repairing and maintaining artillery, gun systems and infantry weapons. Cleaning and lubricating gyroscopes, sights and other electro-optical fire control components. Repairing and maintaining missile mounts, platforms and launch mechanisms. Testing and adjusting weapons firing, guidance and launch systems. Knowledgeable and experienced in electronic and mechanical principles and concepts. Use of electronic, electrical and mechanical test equipment. Use of schematics, drawings, blueprints and wiring diagrams. Operation, testing and maintenance of specific types of weapons systems. Operation and maintenance of fire control systems. Deployed to Afghanistan 05/2010 to 04/2011 Bagram Airfield (BAF) – assisted NCOIC (non-commissioned officer in charge) with day to day operations. These duties included, but were not limited to, scheduling work, inventory tracking, supervision of junior enlisted, and development of training materials, aids and courses. Camp Phoenix, Kabul – NCOIC of small arms repair shop. FOB Airborne and FOB Warehouse – NCOIC of US weapons training mission with ANA (Afghan National Army) and APP (Afghan Provisional Police).

title: Weapons Repair Technician
name: Donald Newman
description: Under the direction of the Armament Supervisor, perform the full range of work involved in the maintenance, storage, and security of small arms and accessories. Serve as Journeyman repairer of small arms to 10/20/30 level maintenance of such weapons as Pistols; M9, M11, Rifles: M16 series, M4 series, M14 series, Submachine guns; M231 series, M249 series. Machine guns: M2 series, M60 series, M240 series, Shotguns: M500 and M590, Grenade Launchers: M203, M320, MK19, Mortars: M224, M252, Field and Towed Howitzers: M119, M198, M777 and all accessories such as BII (Basic Issue Items). Perform the full range of work involved in the maintenance and repair of small arms to 10/20/30/40 level. Responsible for ordering and upkeep of bench stock and maintaining stock usage records. Instruct other employees in the proper repair maintenance procedures and capabilities of small arms, accessories, and BII and special TMDE. Performs other duties as assigned. Knowledgeable and experienced in electronic and mechanical principles and concepts. Use of electronic, electrical and mechanical test equipment. Use of schematics, drawings, blueprints and wiring diagrams. Operation, testing and maintenance of specific types of weapons systems. Operation and maintenance of fire control systems.

title: Weapons Repair Technician
name: Donald Newman
description: Under the supervision of the Armament Supervisor, perform the full range of duties and work involved in the maintenance, storage, and security of small arms and accessories per Army Regulations. Serve as acting supervisor and lead technician of small arms to 10/20/30 level maintenance of such weapons as Pistols; M9, M11, Rifles: M16 series, M4 series, M14 series, Sub-machine guns; M231 series, M249 series. Machine guns: M2 series, M60 series, M240 series, Grenade Launchers: M203, M320, MK19, Mortars: M224, M252, Field and Towed Howitzers: M119, M198, M777 and all accessories such as BII (Basic Issue Items). Perform the full range of work involved in the maintenance and repair of small arms to 10/20/30 level. Responsible for ordering and upkeep of bench stock and maintaining stock usage records. Instruct other employees in the proper repair maintenance procedures and capabilities of small arms, accessories, and BII and special TMDE. Performs other duties as assigned.

title: Weapons Repair Technician
name: Donald Newman
description: Responsible for supervising and performing maintenance and repairs on the mechanisms and systems of tank turrets, tank weapons, fighting vehicles, small arms and other infantry weapons. Duties included: Repairing and maintaining artillery, gun systems and infantry weapons. Cleaning and lubricating gyroscopes, sights and other electro-optical fire control components. Repairing and maintaining missile mounts, platforms and launch mechanisms. Testing and adjusting weapons firing, guidance and launch systems. Knowledgeable and experienced in electronic and mechanical principles and concepts. Use of electronic, electrical and mechanical test equipment. Use of schematics, drawings, blueprints and wiring diagrams. Operation, testing and maintenance of specific types of weapons systems. Operation and maintenance of fire control systems.
